body.name: DreamQuest Mini PC,12th Intel N95 (Up to 3.4Ghz) 16GB RAM 512GB M.2 SSD Windows 11 Pro Preinstalled, Gigabit Ethernet,USB 3.2,4K UHD,Dual Wi-Fi,Bt 4.2 Suitable Home Office
deliveryMessages: Or fastest delivery Friday, February 16. Order within 14 hrs 36 mins
features: Latest 12th Generation Intel Alder Lake-N95 - DreamQuest Mini PC Uses The New 12th Generation Intel Alder Lake N95 Processor (4C/4T, 6M Smart Cache, UP TO 3.4 Ghz, 15W TDP)Performance is up to 36% faster than N5105. In Addition, Mini Computer Is Only 5.1x5.1x1.4 Inches，Easier To Take Anywhere For Flexible Work, Reliable Mini PC Is Designed To Handle Your Daily Tasks.

Versatile Small Desktop Computer - Mini PC Is Equipped With UHD Graphics and 4K Triple-Screen Display. The Built-In Intel UHD Graphics Ensures Faster Image Processing and 4K (4096x2160@60Hz) Video Playback,Providing Powerful Graphics Performance. Ideal For Home Entertainment , Streaming Video, Web Browsing And Working (Supports 4K 60FPS Triple Screen Display)

Stable WiFi 5&Efficient BT4.2 - 2.4GHz+5GHz Dual-Band WiFi Using The Latest Wireless Connection Of 802.11ax, With Speeds Up To 300Mbps. Built-In BT 4.2 Allows You To Connect Multiple Wireless Devices, Such As Mice, Keyboards, Printers And Monitors, With Reliable and Efficient Transmission Speeds, Making It Your Best Choice. Tips: Mini Computers Support Lan Wake-Up, Rtc Wake-Up And Automatic Boot

Mini Computer Upgraded Interface & Efficient Cooling - Mini Computer Is Equipped With a Variety Of Interfaces (1*DC/4*USB 3.2/2*1000M LAN/3*HDMI Port/1*DC Jack) Newly Upgraded 4*USB3.2 Gen2 Port The Operating Speed Is Up To 10 Gbps, and Built-In Ultra-Quiet Fan Radiator Helps Cool Down The Cpu Processor, Reduces Hardware Loss, And Provides Faster Response Speed.

Installed With Windows 11 Pro&Technical Support - Mini PC Comes Pre-Installed with Windows 11 Pro. Supports Linux, Pxe, Ubuntu, Setting Bios On Operating System. Additionally, We Offer a One-Year Limited Warranty And Lifetime Professional Customer Service. Whenever You Need Pre-Sales Or After-Sales Support, Please Feel Free To Contact US.

How to enter the BIOS? Press "Del" during boot to enter BIOS What is the difference between Intel N95 and N5105? The N95 uses a 7nm process and has low power consumption, while the N5105 uses a 14nm process, which has a relatively high power consumption and generates a large amount of heat. Is the MINI PC equipped with a system? It comes with Win 11Pro version

reviews.reviewText: It's great for a desktop. Runs good and solid and quiet

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 9, 2024
reviews.reviewTitle: 4.0 out of 5 stars Cool little thing. No longer available really...
reviews.reviewText: Maybe they will make a n305 mini pc... who knows.. I love the packaging..1.9.24 powered it up. Worked fine. Added 2.5 drive. Worked fine. Bluetooth did not work.Bios = America megatrends* 1/11/24Ah. There is a problem. The small chasis polarizes. I found that out after I ran the mini pc for half a day and it hangs up and when I try to plug in a usb device while it is running it hangs up. My guess a polarized static charge and mr digital logic designer.... didn't know... well.. himpf.. offto buy some foil to make a neutral tap . [It should fix the issue]*9:18p neutral tap added. Yes it works. Iattached it to a rubber foot.*9.14.24 ah.. I forgot what the more correct cable was called... it is called a grounding pigtail wire.

reviews.reviewText: It worked for 4 days straight then all the sudden it stopped it kept saying the computer needs to restart due to some error then it just gave me the Windows window and left it at that never came back on

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on March 1, 2023
reviews.reviewText: just what it says.... great things come in smaller packages

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 4, 2024
reviews.reviewTitle: 2.0 out of 5 stars You get what you pay for
reviews.reviewText: I had read that the new Alderlake N95 chipset was a step above the existing Intel mobile chip offerrings. I bought this PC to do some very low powered tasks as a stand alone machine to free up my other devices. I am not really thrilled.1. This thing is a snail. I don't care what you are doing. This things crawls, locks up and is just generally dissapointing. Even having more then a couple of tabs open on your browser can make Windows hang for a minute or two.2. The transfer speeds through USB 3.0 ports is abysmal. Same storage devices on other machines get 35 to 125 mbs. This thing is luck to push 15 mbs out and that is if you don't move multiple data streams. If so you will look at speeds in the kps range or 0.3. Runs hot. This thing gets really hot when it does anything. And by anything I mean opening a browser, updating Windows. Anything.4. No USB-C. Really? 2023 and that is missing.Conclusion. Spend a little more. Get a Ryzen 5 chipset or something similar. You will be much, much happier.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on December 4, 2022
reviews.reviewTitle: 4.0 out of 5 stars Good system, great price

reviews.reviewText: It is used for home office tasks, programs load in a reasonably short time, and it works perfectly. It's fantastic to have so many ports on such a small PC, very portable, light, and tiny, fits on the palm of your hand. I’m running dual display in my studio and so far it’s running smooth. I didn’t hear any fan noise. Unique mirror and metal design, very awesome on my table, the color and feel is premium, I will not hesitate to introduce my friends to buy it.
I love this little mini. It takes up no space at all on my desk. Its fast and does what I need it too. Well worth the money for the average person. I don't do gaming , I use it for everyday stuff.
very small fits anywhere, fast and easy. Good for everything that I need to do. Great purchase

reviews.reviewTitle: Easy to set up out of the box
reviews.reviewText: Great value for money. Took ten minutes to set up. Works great with zero issues.

---- Updated Nov. 16 2020 ----I am dropping my rating down to 1 star as this PC is performing even worse than I expected. This PC is unable to handle streaming (720p 30fps, 6Mbps) without having the audio drop-out every 15 seconds or so. Occasionally it's not just the audio, but the video as well. I'm not sure if I got a bad unit since other reviewers had good luck, but my experience with this PC has been awful. I do not recommend it to anyone!---- Original Review ----At-a-glance (full review below):PROS:- Compact size- Good number of connectivity options- 2.5G Ethernet port- Easy to open for upgrades, repairs, etc.CONS:- Quite slow, severely limits potential applications- Old WiFi card- Power settings not very clear- Fan is underpowered, causes thermal throttling—— Full Review ——I was looking to add a small form factor PC to my home theatre set-up to use for applications that won’t run on an Apple TV, and for Steam in-home streaming. This mini PC looked to be a decent choice, so I gave it a try.Out of the box, I was very happy with the size of the PC and how easy it was to open the case to access the internals. I am pleased that the PC is quite upgradable, even given its small size: you can add an 2.5” drive, replace the M.2 SSD, swap the WiFi card (though the antennae are glued-in, so this may prove to be difficult), and more. On the outside, there are is a wide array of connectivity options (multiple USB ports, HDMI, etc.) which is useful as it opens up more options for how you can use the PC.The included instructions are quite minimal, but do call-out a few useful settings in the BIOS. There’s a lot more in there though, so a more comprehensive manual would have been nice to see. Additionally, the included mounting bracket only uses one screw, so I’m not sure how much I would trust it (to be fair the PC, is quite light, but still).Unfortunately, my experience setting-up the PC wasn’t as positive as I was hoping. The initial Windows 11 set-up took quite a long time to complete, and after it completed I immediately ran into problems. My HDMI output was no longer working, and without it I wasn’t able to find the shutdown menu (I’m used to Windows 10, not 11). Holding down the power button didn’t seem to do anything, so I ended up needing to unplug the PC to get it to shut down (more on this later). After restarting the PC, I was able to get my display back and perform the (length) Windows 11 updates required.At this point, I took a look at how the hardware appears in the Windows 11 settings. To my surprise, the ethernet port looks to support 2.5G (I was expecting 1G) but I am unable to test this. Despite this nice bonus, the WiFi card leaves a lot to be desired. The installed card is a first-wave WiFi AC Intel card from 2016, which is unexpected given how old that is and the upgraded ethernet port. As mentioned before, you could probably spend $30 to swap the card out for a new WiFi 6E card if you’d like, but I would’ve liked to see at very least a wave-two AC card pre-installed. This also means that the PC cannot connect to WPA3 networks, only WPA2 and below. Given that, I’d only recommend using this PC with a wired ethernet connection. Apart from the connectivity, the CPU, RAM, and M.2 SSD all show-up with the advertised specs.I’m not really happy with the hardware power settings for this PC. As mentioned before, the power button behaviour is not clear. Maybe there’s a BIOS setting for the power button control, but it’s not very intuitive in its default configuration (seems to turn the PC on but not off). Additionally, I’ve run into a few times where the power light indicates the PC is on but it doesn’t respond at all and seems to be in a weird power state (hibernate maybe? not sure here). Again, maybe this behaviour can be changed but with minimal info in the manual, I haven’t had time to dig through the BIOS and figure it out.I tried to use the PC for a few things, and while it performed decently for basic tasks (web browsing, light video watching, etc), it leaves a fair bit to be desired. Despite being advertised as supporting “4k@60Hz” (which it does, if you modify a BIOS setting), it really does not perform well at anything above 1080@60Hz. The hardware video decoding is too slow to sustain the higher resolution and frame rate without dropping frames and causing major latency problems, which makes running Steam Link impossible. Dropping the resolution and refresh rate helps a bit, but it’s still not great. I could see it working for strategy games or more casual games, but trying to stream Portal was painful.Finally, I’m a bit disappointed in the thermal management of the PC. The included fan is indeed very quiet, but this comes at the cost of the PC getting quite hot when in-use. This seems to result in the PC throttling itself to keep temperatures down, and reducing the performance even more, which is disappointing.Overall, this is an okay mini PC for a limited set of applications (light browsing, thin client for a VM, etc.). The price ($258 CAD, with an extra $50 coupon available, at time of review) is not too bad for what you get, but I feel like it’s less of a step-up from a cheap Raspberry Pi, given what I’ll probably be able to use it for. I’d probably not recommend this PC as an HTPC, except for 1080p video streaming only, but it may be okay in other applications.
